In order to make the athletic
program more attractive and to

for Franklin Field, Philadelphia.

Darrow, Bates, Calverton
And Hallgren May 18
The Black and Blue Jay staff will
hear four men of nation-wide fame
at their annual banquet, to be held
at the New Howard Hotel next
Friday, May 18. These four:
Clarence Darrow, Ernest Sutherland Bates, V. F. Calverton, and
Mauritz Hallgren, will be speakers
at a dinner of the Modern Monthly
magazine, which the Jay staff will
attend.
After the dinner of the Modern
Monthly, Mr. Calverton, editor of
that periodical, and a former editor
of the Jay, will address the Jay
staff separately. Mr. Calverton is
a widely known author and lecturer on social and historical subjects.
He has written many books, among
them The Bankruptcy of Marriage,
Three Strange Lovers, and The
Liberation of American Literature.

instructor in English at the Johns
Hopkins University and author,
will leave to become head of the
department of English at Winthrop
College, in Rock Hill, S. C. He
assumes his new post early in September.
Dr. Wheeler, who is co-author
with Dr. John C. French, head librarian at Homewood, of College
Writing and author of a freshman
exercise composition book, Practice
Pages, taught at Goucher College
before joining the Hopkins faculty.
In his second year of teaching at
the girls' college he joined the College for Teachers at the Hopkins.
In 1929 he was appointed instructor
in English in the College of Arts
and Sciences and two years ago was
placed in full charge of all freshman English composition work.

and the winner of tomorrow's fray
will probably go down in stick annals as 1934 champs.

"Gets Students Interested"

PaintersBrash Up
Against Math;
Lose Color
On Monday. morning two painters were lowering themselves down
the north face of Rowland Hall on
a platform which swung just as
listlessly in the breeze as they manipulated their brushes. Coming to
a stop outside of a window they
heard strange sounds within, generated by one of the particularly erudite members of the Mathematics
faculty.
The air was dusty with the chipped particles of massive equations
which the savant was shunting about
with the aid of derricks. Enchanted, they ceased operations completely and in frank astonishment
drank in the entire proceeding for
forty minutes or so. At last the
bell broke up the demonstration and
the professor left the room. After
a minute of reverent silence, one
of the painters asked in an awed
voice, "Do you fellows really understand what he was talking
about?"

Two staff members of the Highland Folk School in Monteagle,
Tennessee, will describe the experimental school there at a luncheon
meeting of the Liberal Club and the
Baltimore Kindergarten for Economic Literacy to be held in LevThe
ering Hall today at 12.30.
speakers are Mr. James Dombrowski and Mr. Rupert Hampton.
Modelled after the famous Danish Folk Schools, the Highland
School was founded two years ago
"for the purpose of training rural
and industrial workers for a new
social order and for conserving and
enriching the native cultural values."

TO END ROAD WORK
With the laying of a black top
having been begun on Wednesday,
it is expected that the construction
of campus roads will be completed
within three weeks. About 356
men are now engaged by the FERA
in finishing the various relief jobs
originally begun last March by the
now defunct CWA.

McKinney'sPosition
In Hopkins R.O.T.C.
According to orders received from
the War Department, Major Carl
F. McKinney, head of the Department of Military Science, will be
transferred to Fort Sam Houston,
Texas, for troop duty with the
Second Division. Major McKinney has served as head of the Hopkins R. 0. T. C. unit for six years,
coming here in July, 1928.
Major Gregory Hoisington, who
served in Major McKinney's present capacity at Hopkins for several
years prior to 1928, will be retransferred from Frot Leavenworth
to his former position here.
These changes become effective
by the first of July, it was announced, and Major Hoisington will
be in full charge of the Hopkins
unit at the opening of the fall term
in October.

Mr. Carlyle Barton, member of
the Board of Trustees and a prominentlawyer,addressed the assembly.
"The student should not think
too much of the debt which the
University owes him, but rather
more about the debt which he owes
the University," declared Mr. Barton.

Caution Money Balance
Beginning today and continuing
through until next Friday, an intensive subscription drive will be
carried on by the recently-appointed
Cage Committee for funds with
which to speed up the erection of a
suitable cage.
The aim of the group is to raise
an amount of not less than $5,000
directly by student donations. Payments are to be made in cash or deductions from the student's caution
money with his: written consent.

Students Pay Only Part

Speaking about the total amount
of tuition payed by the students of
Johns Hopkins he declared that
"the students pay only one quarter
of the $3,000,000 which it costs to
run the University." The remainder is paid by those persons, he
said, like the founder, Johns Hopkins, who have felt a true desire to
aid and support ,the University, and
have made contributions to it, or
have left it their estates.
Commenting on the nation-wide
collegiate activity concerning the
R. 0. T. C., the speaker reminded
the students of the debt which they
owe to the country of their forefathers which has given them so
many advantages. The country
can only be protected by its police,
which is the military organization.
Criticize Lack Of Knowledge

Mr. Barton also pointed out that
many of the members of college
faculties throughout the country are
constantly criticizing the capitalistic
system which enables them to live
their camparitively secluded lives.
This criticism often comes from a
lack of knowledge of the practical
side of economics which often make
certain actions necessary in the business world.
The speaker also reminded the
students that, when they are in the
business world, they should find the
real reason behind things before
they endeavor to reform them according to theories learned in college.

Point To Precedent

It was pointed out by Ted Stern,
who is serving as co-chairman of
the committee along with Ed Sadtler, that a similar drive in 1928 netted $8,800 in student donations.
He urged every member of the
University to contribute as generously as possible in order to insure
the building of the cage.

Even glass insulators behave badly toward telephone currents when humidity is high. This has
been proved by experiments at Bell Telephone
Laboratories.
When it's humid, a film of moisture forms on
the glass. The more humid, the thicker the film
— and the more electrical current escapes! Important factors governing amount of leakage are
the chemical nature of the glass, its shape and age,
the amount and kind of dirt on its surface.
Through exhaustive studies,telephone men have
developed more efficient types of glass insulators
— and are seeking ways to make them still better.
Close attention to every detail of Bell System
equipment leads to constantly improving service.

In an attempt to score points in
the Middle Atlantic Collegiates,
Coach Waldo Hambleton will send
a select squad to Lafayette today
and tomorrow to compete in the annual classic. The Jays have been
represented ever since traq< has
flourished at the University, and
they succeeded in obtaining a first
place in team scoreing in 1923-24.
The only champion sporting the
Black and Blue is Paul Holtzman,
two mile ace, who defeated a large
field in this event last year. Holtzman, however, will meet strong opposition, chief among whom will be
Smith of Rutgers. Smith looms as
a potential winner, and Holtzman
will be forced to his best efforts in
order to win.
New, Weeks Garner Points

Other members of this year's
varsity that scored points in the
1933 event are Will Neu and Johnny Weeks, who took second and
third, respectively in the broad
jump. These men will compete in
their specialties again on Saturday,
while Neu will also run in the 100yard dash.
Another member of the Jays who
is expected to perform extremely
well is Johnny King, distance ace.
King has been defeated only once
this season in the mile, and is one
of the foremost challengers for the
championship.

Although beaten by Mt. Washington in their debut, 8 to 4, the
Annapolis players seem to have
taken a new lease on life and are
more determined than ever to add
the '34 title to their national victories in '29, '30 and '31.
St. John's has only to defeat the
Jays tomorrow to have a substantial
claim to the national title, while
Hopkins will have to beat the Johnnies and then Maryland to have a
clear claim for top honors.

PACKARD
It is a far cry from wielding a
lacrosse stick to swaying the emotions of a congregation, but George
F. Packard, veteran lacrosseman, is
bound to make the leap.
Now in his senior year, Packard
expects to enter the Seminary of
Alexander in Virginia upon his
graduation from the Hopkins, in
order to become an Episcopal minister.
Due to extensive studying, Packard was unable to participate in lacrosse until the recent Penn game.
His return
will
undoubtedly
strengthen the Jay stick team for
its two coming major clashes.
George did not play in his regular
position as center against Penn, but
was used as second attack, due to
the need for greater scoring power.
Packard first played lacrosse at
Marstons out Ruxton way under
the tutelage of Happy Middleton,
new coach of the University of
Pennsylvania.
Not only does he play lacrosse,
but he was also a member of the
cross country team for three years.

to advance dope, appear evenly

PaintersBrash Up
Against Math;
Lose Color
On Monday. morning two painters were lowering themselves down
the north face of Rowland Hall on
a platform which swung just as
listlessly in the breeze as they manipulated their brushes. Coming to
a stop outside of a window they
heard strange sounds within, generated by one of the particularly erudite members of the Mathematics
faculty.
The air was dusty with the chipped particles of massive equations
which the savant was shunting about
with the aid of derricks. Enchanted, they ceased operations completely and in frank astonishment
drank in the entire proceeding for
forty minutes or so. At last the
bell broke up the demonstration and
the professor left the room. After
a minute of reverent silence, one
of the painters asked in an awed
voice, "Do you fellows really understand what he was talking
about?"

The aim of the group is to raise
an amount of not less than $5,000
directly by student donations. Payments are to be made in cash or deductions from the student's caution
money with his: written consent.

Students Pay Only Part

Speaking about the total amount
of tuition payed by the students of
Johns Hopkins he declared that
"the students pay only one quarter
of the $3,000,000 which it costs to
run the University." The remainder is paid by those persons, he
said, like the founder, Johns Hopkins, who have felt a true desire to
aid and support ,the University, and
have made contributions to it, or
have left it their estates.
Commenting on the nation-wide
collegiate activity concerning the
R. 0. T. C., the speaker reminded
the students of the debt which they
owe to the country of their forefathers which has given them so
many advantages. The country
can only be protected by its police,
which is the military organization.
Criticize Lack Of Knowledge

Mr. Barton also pointed out that
many of the members of college
faculties throughout the country are
constantly criticizing the capitalistic
system which enables them to live
their camparitively secluded lives.
This criticism often comes from a
lack of knowledge of the practical
side of economics which often make
certain actions necessary in the business world.
The speaker also reminded the
students that, when they are in the
business world, they should find the
real reason behind things before
they endeavor to reform them according to theories learned in college.

Point To Precedent

It was pointed out by Ted Stern,
who is serving as co-chairman of
the committee along with Ed Sadtler, that a similar drive in 1928 netted $8,800 in student donations.
He urged every member of the
University to contribute as generously as possible in order to insure
the building of the cage.

Even glass insulators behave badly toward telephone currents when humidity is high. This has
been proved by experiments at Bell Telephone
Laboratories.
When it's humid, a film of moisture forms on
the glass. The more humid, the thicker the film
— and the more electrical current escapes! Important factors governing amount of leakage are
the chemical nature of the glass, its shape and age,
the amount and kind of dirt on its surface.
Through exhaustive studies,telephone men have
developed more efficient types of glass insulators
— and are seeking ways to make them still better.
Close attention to every detail of Bell System
equipment leads to constantly improving service.

Jack King In Mile

Ancient Rivals To Settle National Lacrosse Title At
Jays To End Season Against
Homewood Tomorrow
Maryland Next Wednes(Continued from Page 1, Col. 1)
day; Rally Planned
Beaten By Mounts In Debut

In an attempt to score points in
the Middle Atlantic Collegiates,
Coach Waldo Hambleton will send
a select squad to Lafayette today
and tomorrow to compete in the annual classic. The Jays have been
represented ever since traq< has
flourished at the University, and
they succeeded in obtaining a first
place in team scoreing in 1923-24.
The only champion sporting the
Black and Blue is Paul Holtzman,
two mile ace, who defeated a large
field in this event last year. Holtzman, however, will meet strong opposition, chief among whom will be
Smith of Rutgers. Smith looms as
a potential winner, and Holtzman
will be forced to his best efforts in
order to win.
New, Weeks Garner Points

Other members of this year's
varsity that scored points in the
1933 event are Will Neu and Johnny Weeks, who took second and
third, respectively in the broad
jump. These men will compete in
their specialties again on Saturday,
while Neu will also run in the 100yard dash.
Another member of the Jays who
is expected to perform extremely
well is Johnny King, distance ace.
King has been defeated only once
this season in the mile, and is one
of the foremost challengers for the
championship.

Although beaten by Mt. Washington in their debut, 8 to 4, the
Annapolis players seem to have
taken a new lease on life and are
more determined than ever to add
the '34 title to their national victories in '29, '30 and '31.
St. John's has only to defeat the
Jays tomorrow to have a substantial
claim to the national title, while
Hopkins will have to beat the Johnnies and then Maryland to have a
clear claim for top honors.

PACKARD
It is a far cry from wielding a
lacrosse stick to swaying the emotions of a congregation, but George
F. Packard, veteran lacrosseman, is
bound to make the leap.
Now in his senior year, Packard
expects to enter the Seminary of
Alexander in Virginia upon his
graduation from the Hopkins, in
order to become an Episcopal minister.
Due to extensive studying, Packard was unable to participate in lacrosse until the recent Penn game.
His return
will
undoubtedly
strengthen the Jay stick team for
its two coming major clashes.
George did not play in his regular
position as center against Penn, but
was used as second attack, due to
the need for greater scoring power.
Packard first played lacrosse at
Marstons out Ruxton way under
the tutelage of Happy Middleton,
new coach of the University of
Pennsylvania.
Not only does he play lacrosse,

B Entry Tops Rival
in Indoor Twin Bill
Decisive Victory Gained Over
Students Of "C" Entry
Last Week
A very decisive victory was
gained by the students of "B" entry
last Sunday over the students of
"C" entry in an indoor baseball
double-header played in front of
the dorms.
"B" entry fielded excellently,
making only four errors in the two
games. Rogers, the "C" pitcher,
was driven to cover in the first
game after being hit hard. To
Byer, Coliveras, Bachman and
Houstre goes the credit for the
scores of "B", 35; "C", 9—"B",
14; "C", 4. Jerry Bloom was the
lone star among the underdogs, but
the odds were too great.

Van Orman Dissatisfied

Coach Van Orman seems far
from satisfied with the showing of
his charges in their last two encounters. The Blue Jays were
never extended and seemed satisfied
to coast through to victory. At the
initial practice for the all-important
tilt tomorrow, Van Orman prophesied a defeat for the Jays unless
they bucked up and showed some
spirit and fight.
